Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Ernie O'Malley Papers AIA 060
40.75 Linear Feet in 29 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, and 13 oversize flat boxes.
1643-2010 1920-1957 Materials are in English, Irish, German, and Spanish. Ernie O'Malley was an Irish Republican Army officer during the Irish War of Independence of 1919-1921 and a senior commander of the anti-treaty IRA during the Irish Civil War, 1922-1923. During the course of the war he was wounded, captured, and participated in a hunger strike. After the war he traveled in Europe and in the United States to raise funds for the Irish Press. O'Malley was a man of diverse intellectual and artistic interests, which led him to live in New Mexico and New York and travel in Mexico. He was married to American artist Helen Hooker in 1935, the two moved to Ireland, divorcing in 1952. O'Malley died in 1957.
The collection contains manuscript works of Ernie O'Malley and other individuals; correspondence, both personal and business-related; finacial and legal records; materials concerning art and art-collecting; and nationalist material including military training manuals, diaries, clippings, and financial and legal material. Of special interest are drafts and publicity related to several of O'Malley's works including On Another Man's Wound, The Singing Flame (published in the United States as Army without Banners), Raids and Rallies, and several poems. Of note is correspondence between O'Malley and the artist Jack B. Yeats. Additional series contain materials collected by O'Malley and his son Cormac O'Malley.
Arrangement
Collection is arranged into 15 series. Files are arranged alphabetically except where noted.
Collection is arranged into 15 series, some of which are further arranged into subseries. Series are arranged either alphabetically or chronologically.

Use Restrictions
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Ernie O'Malley are held by Cormac O'Malley. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which he holds copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting Cormac O'Malley.

Historical/Biographical Note
Ernie O'Malley (1897-1957) was an Irish Republican Army officer during the Irish War of Independence of 1919-1921 and a senior commander of the anti-treaty IRA during the Irish Civil War, 1922-1923. O'Malley wrote four books, On Another Man's Wound, The Singing Flame, Raids and Rallies, Sean Connolly of Longford in addition to numerous poems, short stories, articles and reviews. A renaissance man, O'Malley was interested in art, archaeology, folklore, photography, literature and history, but also in the lives of those he fought with during the Irish Independence movement. In the 1950s he interviewed over 450 survivors of those he had fought along with, and these interviews were the basis for the episodes covered in his Raids and Rallies and Sean Connolly.
O'Malley was studying medicine at University College Dublin in 1916 when the Easter Rising took place. Although not a nationalist at the time, O'Malley having been invited by some friends to help defend Trinity College, Dublin in case the Irish Volunteers attempted to take it over, he decided his sympathies were with the rebels and thus began his military career. When he went on the run in 1917, he was asked by Michael Collins to organize IRA brigade units throughout rural Ireland and later as a Commandant General, at age 24, he commanded the IRA's Second Southern Division in Munster with 7,000 men. O'Malley was captured twice during his military career, the first time by the British in Kilkenny in December 1920 after which he was interrogated and badly beaten. With the threat of execution imminent he, and two other IRA men, escaped from Kilmainham Jail on February 14, 1921. At this arrest he had identified himself as 'Bernard Stewart' and when he escaped, his true identity was still unknown. O'Malley was captured a second time in the civil war on November 4, 1922 after a shoot-out with Free State troops in a house in Dublin. Critically wounded, he managed to survive prison for almost two years and 41 days on hunger strike before finally being released in July of 1924. Although still not well, he decided to seek a warmer climate hoping to recover both physically and spiritually and traveled in Europe spending time hiking in the Pyrenes, museum hopping and self-studying art and architecture while constantly writing. After returning to medical studies in Dublin for 1926-28, he was asked to go with Frank Aiken to the United States by Eamon de Valera to raise funds for the establishment of a new independent newspaper, The Irish Press. His notes and impressions of these journeys, 1928-1935, are included in the collection in Notebook Series and elsewhere in the Correspondence Series. O'Malley settled in Taos and Santa Fe, New Mexico for 1929-1932 and while there met many artists and writers and occasionally lectured on modern Irish history and literature while writing his memoirs. He also traveled extensively in Mexico in 1931 for nine months following his interests in folklore, archaeology, modern Mexican art and teaching, - all the while writing.
In 1932 during the height of the Depression, O'Malley returned to New York to finish and publish his memoir, On Another Man's Wound. With introductions from Paul Strand, met many of the city's literary, theatre and artistic circles. He continued to write articles, poems and short stories, but only his poems were published. The manuscript for his memoir was rejected many times. In the meantime with the change in government in Ireland, he became eligible for a pension for his military service and wounds, and this led to his return to Ireland to secure his pension. While in New York he also met his future wife here, Helen Hooker, a sculptor and photographer, who had travelled extensively in Europe and Russia. Helen was the daughter of Elon Huntington Hooker, a wealthy businessman and founder of Hooker Electrochemical Company from Greenwich, Connecticut. When he returned to Ireland in 1935 she followed him. They married on September 27, 1935, and he returned to medical school. The couple settled initially in Dublin and later in County Mayo, Ireland, on a farm. O'Malley continued writing and Helen continued her sculpture, photography and theatre interests. The couple had three children. After the marriage broke down in the late 1940s and Helen effectively returned to the United States, seized two of the children, Cathal and Etain, and brought then to America where she initiated divorce proceedings in 1950. O'Malley's youngest son, Cormac, remained with his father. The divorce was finalized in 1952. After being in poor health for several years Ernie O'Malley died in 1957 in Dublin.
During his lifetime, O'Malley published one critically acclaimed work about his experiences in the Irish War for Independence: On Another Man's Wound. His second volume, The Singing Flame, covering the Civil War was only published posthumously. O'Malley had published a series of articles in The Sunday Press in 1955-56 describing his and other fighters' experiences, using the interviews he had conducted with former IRA men. These were also published after his death as Raids and Rallies. The collection includes this serialization as well as reviews and publicity on these works and others in the Clippings and Publicity Series.
In 1991, Prisoners: The Civil War Letters of Ernie O'Malley was published by his son Cormac and Richard English, the latter who also went on to write his biography, Ernie O'Malley: IRA Intellectual in 1998. In 2007, Cormac edited and published No Surrender Here!The Civil War Papers of Ernie O'Malley, 1922-1924, being a compilation of anti-Treaty military communications and his father's letters from prison during the Civil War. Cormac also edited and published Rising-Out: Sean Connolly of Longford, 1890-1921 in 2007. Broken Landscapes: Selected Letters of Ernie O'Malley, 1924-1957, also co-edited by Cormac and Nicholas Allen was published in 2011.
Existence and Location of Originals
Collection contains photocopies of original documents held by other repositories. The location of some originals is unknown.

Scope and Content Note
This collection documents the personal, intellectual, and artistic interests and activities of the Ernie O'Malley. Materials documenting his participating in the Irish War of Independence and the Irish Civil War include manuscript material, collected military manuals, and interviews conducted with other veterans. Art catalogs, clippings, research files, correspondence with other artists, and poetry appear throughout the collection, illustrating O'Malley's keen interest in art and literature. Essays, articles, poetry, short stories, drawings, and manuscripts of his major works comprise a large portion of the collection. Correspondence with colleagues, friends, and family also make up a significant part of the collection. Further records document the personal, legal, and financial aspects of O'Malley's life. Also included are materials collected by O'Malley and his son, Cormac O'Malley, related to Irish literature and history.
Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
The collection was donated to Tamiment Library in December 2010 by Cormac O'Malley, son of Ernie O'Malley. The accession number associated with this gift is 2010.092. An addition donation was received in July 2012. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2012.066 and 2012.089.
Processing Information
Original ordering schemas, when present, were retained, including various alphanumeric systems to label notebooks and diaries. Not all notations on items within the collection are original to Ernie O'Malley; some are by Cormac O'Malley. Some folders contain explanatory information provided by Cormac O'Malley.

Arrangement
Material in Subseries IA is listed alphabetically by title or nature of work. Material in Subseries IB is listed by author and title of the work and organized alphabetically.
Scope and Content Note
The series contains two subseries. Subseries A. Ernie O'Malley comprises literary manuscripts, articles, book reviews, essays, short stories, poetry, notes, drawings and speeches written or created by Ernie O'Malley between the years of 1926 and 1956. Published and unpublished works, manuscript drafts, reprints and photocopies are represented. A considerable amount of O'Malley's works were written during his travels throughout the United States and Mexico between 1928 and 1935. A substantial portion of his literary output centers on his homeland, his military experiences during both the Irish War of Independence and Civil War, early Christian art in Ireland and Irish artists. Other works reflect his interest in art, poetry and a variety of other topics. Materials within the Works series are manuscript and/or typescript and are so indicated.
Works by other authors are found in Subseries B. Other Writers. Throughout his life O'Malley collected ballads and poetry written by others. While most of these materials were either transcribed by O'Malley himself or typed for his personal reference or use, several of the items are clippings or printed materials sent to him by friends and colleagues. Poets within this series include both American and European poets such as Lascelles Abercrombie, Hart Crane, Emily Dickinson, Horace Gregory, James Joyce, Stanley Kunitz, Ezra Pound, Seamus O'Sullivan, John Millington Synge and numerous others. Additional works by others include articles, plays and essays sent to O'Malley for his consideration, review and comment.
For additional materials relating to the works and literary output of Ernie O'Malley see Series 10: Diaries, Notebooks and Research.Subseries IA. Processing Information
This series was originally divided into American and Non-American correspondents but these have been combined into one set of incoming correspondence. The separate indices for these listings are included in the index for the series.
Arrangement
Files are arranged alphabetically by surname.
Scope and Content Note
Included are letters, telegrams, greeting cards and postcards sent to Ernie O'Malley between the years of 1922 and 1956. The correspondence in this series is of a personal nature, detailing O'Malley's friendships and associations, as well as, a business nature documenting O'Malley's dealings with publishers, solicitors, and government agencies. Throughout the course of his life O'Malley maintained friendships with notable artists, poets and writers in both Ireland and the United States. Of special interest are the postcards and letters sent to O'Malley while he was imprisoned at Kilmainham Jail and Curragh Camp during the Irish Civil War in 1923 and 1924.
A limited number of items in this series are photocopies received from various universities, institutions, or private family collections at the request of Cormac O'Malley, Ernie O'Malley's youngest son. Throughout the course of research on his father Cormac O'Malley also transcribed a considerable number of the letters written by Ernie O'Malley. Those transcriptions have been included with the original or photocopy when available. Correspondence: Outgoing1922-1956
Scope and Content Note
Letters from Ernie O'Malley to friends, associates, artists, editors, professors, military comrades, government agencies, solicitors, and other correspondents in Ireland and the United States between the years of 1922 and 1956. Topics in this series range broadly from general greetings to business dealings. Many of the letters provide insight into O'Malley's ailments and failing health resulting from injuries he sustained during his military career. Of special interest are letters O'Malley wrote concerning his work with the Irish Press in the United States and the status of his pension from the Irish government, as well as, transcriptions of letters from O'Malley to Monsignor John Hagan with O'Malley using the alias, Cecil Smyth-Howard, during his European travels in 1925 and 1926. A substantial number of items in this series are photocopies received from various universities and institutions, at the request of Cormac O'Malley, Ernie O'Malley's youngest son. Throughout the course of research on his father Cormac O'Malley also transcribed a considerable number of the letters written by Ernie O'Malley. Those transcriptions have been included with the original or photocopy when available. See accompanying index for a complete listing of correspondents indicating where originals are currently held, as well as, the volume of correspondence associated with each correspondent.Index to Correspondence: Outgoing20104112Aiken, Frank1928-19324113Ames, Elizabeth (Yaddo)19324114Beaslia, Piaras19534115Brady, JimJan 30, 19494115ABrady, Kathleen (Kay)1925-19264116Brennan, Maurteen (Martin)19514117Brett, Dorothy19304118British and Irish Steam Packet Co.19384119Childers, Mary Alden Osgood (Mrs. Erskine Childers)1923-19244120Childers, Mary Alden Osgood (Mrs. Erskine Childers) (see also Subject Files)19234121Citkowitz-Liber, Rebecca19524122Clifford-Comer, Madge (Mrs. Jack Comer)1924-19374123Comer, EllisDec 30, 19374124Davis, Chester C. Arrangement
Series is arranged alphabetically by type, generally.
Scope and Content Note
Address books, memberships, book slips, inventories, lists, invitations, announcements, school records, memorabilia and other miscellaneous materials covering various events in Ernie O'Malley's life. Throughout the course of his life O'Malley, an avid reader, acquired a vast and diverse personal library. Due to financial hardships during the late 1940s and early 1950s O'Malley was forced to sell a substantial portion of books from his personal library. Card catalogs and inventories in this series reflect the many changes in his personal collection of books before and following the sale. Of special interest is a collection of book slips from the National Library of Ireland, New York Public Library and Newberry Library in Chicago, Illinois documenting the hundreds of books O'Malley read or checked out from each institution during the 1930s.Index to Personal201061AAddress Book: United States19284228Address Books1944-195561Address Books1950-195562Address Book19534229Catlogue of Printed Books: Southeby & Company, London (2 copies)194963Ernie O'Malley and Helen Hungtington Hooker - scrapbook of articles by and aboutDec 200664Funeral PhotographsMar 195764AInventories of Booksundated65Inventories of Books - typed and annotatedundated66Inventories of Books: Missing books195067Inventory of Books: Card catalog slips (inventory of O'Malley book collection) and handwritten Spanish flashcards (5-8 in inventory)undated30Inventory of Books: Card catalog slips (inventory of O'Malley book collection) and handwritten Spanish flashcards (5-8 in inventory)undated31Inventory of Books: Book slipscirca 1932-194032

Scope and Content Note
The series contains legal documents and clippings relating to Ernie O'Malley between the years of 1923 and 1957. Most materials in this series relate to the legal proceedings between O'Malley and his estranged wife, Helen Hooker O'Malley in 1950. Also included are clippings documenting the libel lawsuit and settlement between Joseph O'Doherty and Ernie O'Malley following O'Malley's publication of On Another Man's Wound. Nationalistic Material1643-1966, undated
Arrangement
Materials in this series are in two groups: military training manuals, arranged chronologically, and printed material, arranged alphabetically.
Scope and Content Note
This series contains newspaper clippings, booklets, notes, pamphlets, military training manuals, reports, memorandums, photographs and other printed matter relating to the nationalist movement in Ireland. Drawn to the nationalist cause in midst of the Easter Rising in 1916, O'Malley later joined the Irish Republican Army and became a key figure in the War of Independence and Irish Civil War. Items in this series provide details of O'Malley's military career, as well as, insight into the publications and propaganda that powered the nationalist movement throughout Ireland. Also included in this series are official reports and memoranda issued by Oglaigh na hEireann, otherwise known as the Irish Republican Army. Of special interest in this series are a few items relating to O'Malley's interviews with veterans of the War of Independence and Civil War. Beginning in the early 1940s, O'Malley embarked on an ambitious effort to document first-hand accounts of both wars and as a result, hand-recorded approximately 450 interviews with his former military comrades. Most items relating to his military interviews were placed in the archives of University College Dublin in 1974, however, a limited amount of materials pertaining to the interviews remain in this series.Index to Nationalistic material2010712Military Training Manual: Field Service Pocketbook,1914 with 1916 amendments (signed)1916713Military Training Manual: Musketry Consisting of Theory of Rifle Fire 1. Jack B. Yeats1904-1980
Scope and Content Note
The series contains correspondence, articles, clippings, invitations, cancelled checks, receipts, notes, exhibition catalogs, stamps and photographs collected by Ernie O'Malley relating to Jack B. Yeats, as well as, items relating to Yeats' father, John B. Yeats, and brother, William Butler Yeats. Items in this series are of both a personal and professional nature. O'Malley and Jack B. Yeats met in Ireland during the 1930s and developed a friendship that lasted until their deaths in 1957. In addition to being a patron of Yeats' artwork, O'Malley served on the Jack B. Yeats National Loan Exhibition Committee and authored the introduction for the exhibition's catalog in 1945. Throughout the course of their friendship Yeats gifted O'Malley various pencil sketches and writings by John B. Yeats, in addition to several letters written by the elder Yeats to his other son, William Butler Yeats. Other items include Yeats materials collected by Ernie O'Malley's son, Cormac O'Malley.Index to Jack B. Diaries, Notes and Research1922-1963
Arrangement
The series is arranged chronologically, with Notes arranged alphabetically by subject and filed at the end of the series.
Scope and Content Note
This series contains diaries, journals, notebooks, loose notes and research by Ernie O'Malley contextualizing his literary output and body of work. Items in this series reflect the commentary, criticisms, critiques and general notes taken by O'Malley on a variety of topics including art, literature, poetry and history, and provide insight into his research methodology and writing process. Most notebooks in this series are untitled, however, some notebooks bear the letters "P" indicating painting, or "I" for Ireland. Of special interest in this series are O'Malley's diaries from his travels in the United States and Mexico, as well as, notebooks relating to his military career. See the accompanying index for an itemized listing, description and full summary of each notebook in this series. Additional notebooks and notes may be found in Series 1: Works and Series 12: Art Materials.Index to Diaries, Notes and Research2010927

Arrangement
The series is arranged chronologically.
Scope and Content Note
This series includes newspaper clippings, book reviews, magazine features, advertisements, book covers and correspondence relating to Ernie O'Malley, his literary output and posthumous publications. Many of the clippings in this series were collected by O'Malley and reflect his general interests in art, literature, poetry, theatre and current affairs. Clippings also relate to international affairs and historic events including the Second World War, Spanish Civil War and Anglo-Irish relations. O'Malley collected articles of interest from both American and European newspapers including, The New York Times, Irish Independent and Irish Press. This series also contains clippings detailing O'Malley's funeral, as well as, book reviews and other items pertaining to the publication of On Another Man's Wound and its German translation, Rebellen en Irlande. Additional items in this series relate to the publicity of books published after his death by O'Malley's son Cormac O'Malley and Richard English including Prisoners: The Civil War Letters of Ernie O'Malley and Richard English's Ernie O'Malley: IRA Intellectual.Index to Clippings and publicity2010171Clippings collected by Ernie O'Malley1895-1949172Clippings: various including family, death notice, donation of papers to University College Dublin1922-1990175Clippings collected by Ernie O'Malley (see index for list)1921-1948173Clippings: wounding and capturing of O'Malley1922-1957174Reviews of Ernie O'Malley books I1928-1992176Reviews of Ernie O'Malley books II1928-1992177Clippings re: Marriage O'Malley-Hooker; Arts Material 1918-1955
Scope and Content Note
Notebooks, notes, works, lectures, clippings, magazine articles, photographs, postcards, reprints of artwork, brochures, sketches, exhibition catalogues, theatre programs and printed materials reflecting O'Malley's interest in painting, sculpture, architecture, archeology, music and theatre throughout Europe, Mexico and the United States. Many of the clippings, magazine articles and reprints were collected by O'Malley as research for his articles and essays on painting, sculpture, archeology, architecture and other related topics. A substantial number of art catalogues and theatre programs were deposited at University College Dublin by O'Malley's son, Cormac O'Malley, in 1974. Photocopies of the aforementioned items remain in this series, along with nearly 50 original art catalogues and theatre programs. Also included in this series are more than 200 copies of photographs taken by O'Malley, Helen Hooker O'Malley and others from Mexico and Ireland. Of special interest are notes taken by O'Malley during a series of interviews he conducted with organizers of the Irish Exhibition of Living Art during the 1940s. O'Malley's interest in art criticism encouraged him to embark on series of interviews with some of Ireland's most prominent modern artists including, Evie Hone, Jack Hanlon, Louis le Brocquy, Norah McGuinness, Nano Reid and many others. Scope and Content Note
Art exhibition catalogues, theatre programs, clippings, bills, receipts, correspondence, graphic materials and printed matter collected by Ernie O'Malley and organized chronologically by his son, Cormac O'Malley. Items in this series document his routine activities, and some expenses, as well as, many of friends and associates. A number of the items in this series are photocopies of originals housed elsewhere in the collection, but left here for handy chronological reference.Chronology Files: Index201021211920-19231920-19232122192219222123192319232124

Processing Information
The original inventory listed two separate series for Subject Files: American and Non-American; the latter described as: "Correspondence, clippings, brochures, photographs, greeting cards, interview notes, printed matter and other ephemeral material pertaining to topics or people associated with Ernie O'Malley or his son, Cormac O'Malley with an American connection." These have been combined into one alphabetical run.
Arrangement
Series is arranged alphabetically.
Scope and Content Note
The bulk of this series consists of research notes and correspondence between Cormac O'Malley and individuals, organizations and institutions associated with his father. Other items include correspondence, clippings, brochures, photographs, greeting cards, interview transcripts, audio reels, printed matter and other ephemeral material pertaining to topics or people associated with Ernie O'Malley or his son, Cormac O'Malley. Throughout the course of his research on his father, Cormac O'Malley worked with his father's friends and their descendents, as well as, numerous universities, libraries, biographers and documentary film makers. In 1970, Cormac O'Malley conducted a series of interviews with Madge and Jack Comer, Sigle Humphreys, Thomas and Peggy Malone, Sean Lemass, Peadar O'Donnell and George Gilmore documenting personal accounts and the military experiences of Ernie O'Malley. The transcriptions of these interviews, as well as, three 1/4" audio reels are housed within this series. Of special interest are materials collected by Ernie O'Malley relating to the Irish Press detailing his travels and expenses, in addition to, the funds he raised for the newspaper. Many of the items in this series are photocopies of originals housed elsewhere in the collection.Subject Files: Indices (14 and 14A)20102227Aiken, Frank1982-20052228American Indian Dance Festivalscirca 19292228A

Scope and Content Note
Items in this series reflect O'Malley's varied interests in Irish history, cartography, art and many other areas and include prints, reprints, maps, photographs, essays, brochures, letters, drawings, reproductions and other ephemeral materials and artifacts collected or inherited by Ernie O'Malley. While most of the graphic items in this series are reprints or reproductions, several original cards, drawings and paintings from notable artists including Roy Boynton, and Jack Hanlon are also included. Nearly twenty maps and nine letters either written by or addressed to historically significant Irishmen and women including Eva Gore Booth, Standish O' Grady, Sean O'Sullivan and Thomas Grattan complete the series as well as an undated historic account of the Spanish Armada's landing and an indenture for land dated 1857.Printed Ephemera Index20102735Account: "Spanish Fleet Landing in Kinsdale, Ireland in 1601" handwritten, [John Blake Dillon?]undated2736"Adventures in Music" [Orchestral Concert Series]19464223Applegood, Frank G.: "Domingo" photocopy of engraving; Taos, NMpre 1932281"The Blasket Island from Dun Quin" (print of woodcut)undated2811Christmas card by Jack Hanlon, signed by artistcirca 19452740Christmas card signed by Jack B.
